title: Do I have to pay medical bills that date back to 2008-2010?
question: I just received a letter in the mail informing me that legal action will be taken if I don't settle my medical debt.
answers:
If you have not made a payment in over 4 years then if the Creditor sues you in court you will need to raise the defense of the "Statute of Limitations". Collectors file lawsuits all the time to collect on the debt they bought for pennies on the dollar, for the full amount of the debt + costs of collection.
The debt, after the 4 years becomes 'zombie' debt, dead debt that hangs around on your credit record for 10 years or longer as the debt buyers try to re age the debt by listing the date of the debt as the date it was purchased, not the true date of the debt.
You may have other financial issues that would also be remedied by a discharge in bankruptcy and you won't know unless you speak to a qualified bankruptcy attorney.

A lawsuit can be filed by almost anyone that wants to pay the filing fee. If they have a valid claim and there is no defense to it, they can collect. If a lawsuit is filed, the plaintiff can show an arguable claim to the court, you are served and do nothing, the plaintiff can get a judgment that you will have to pay.

However, in your situation it sounds like you have a defense, the "Statute of Limitations". You must present that defense to the court if you are sued by filing a formal "Answer", paying the filing fee and showing up when you have to . If you don't, you lose.

In some situations, a creditor that threatens legal action when that legal action is defensible by the Statute of Limitations might be violating the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act or other laws. If harassment by this creditor becomes an issue, seek legal advice. Keep track of what you are sent and make notes of what you are told over the phone. Get dates, times, names and phone numbers.
You can raise the defense that it is beyond the statute of limitations. If you have other debts you can't pay you may want to look into bankruptcy. Good Luck!

You are probably beyond the statue of limitations. Debt collectors are not known for high ethical standards or following the law. To properly answer your questions and address your concerns, the best way to handle this is with an in person consultation with an experienced CA bankruptcy attorney.
